{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3446304,"name":"","username":"Christian","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/b2d939/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-11-11T22:15:51.034Z","cooked":"

This is wolfgang first time doing swerve and were having some issue with Thrifty Absolute Magnetic Encoder its like the sensor are not reading, sometimes some wheels doesn’t change angles. Does anyone know how to fix this issue. Swerve Video

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":32,"updated_at":"2024-11-11T22:17:36.103Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":173,"reads":355,"readers_count":354,"score":936.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":474713,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-thrifty-encoder","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://drive.google.com/file/d/1upr3t-Ghb_1AidX4GUPnFsjBKfiIB6DC/view?usp=sharing","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"IMG_5770.MOV - Google Drive","clicks":47}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66460,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-thrifty-encoder/474713/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3446308,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2024-11-11T22:22:14.841Z","cooked":"

Welcome!

Could you provide more detail of what you are expecting to happen?
(E.g, drive to the left of the video, sit still with no motor motion, spin in a circle, etc)

Knowing the test program will help us diagnose the issue.

Now, assuming it is meant to be sitting still, does this behavior persist when the bot is placed on a carpet?

The default PID values (assuming they are in the correct ballpark for the gear ratios/motors/sensors) will assume some level of friction against the floor. Sitting up on blocks means this doesn’t happen and you may get some erratic behaviour.

Ok. Very helpful video.

I would double check all your ratios and conversion factors, Also do what @chadr03 said and make sure you get the values out of the encoders you are expecting on the smart dashboard.

Next step beyond that is to dig into PID values and any gyro feedback you may be using for field-centric control.

I suspect you have conversion factors/ratios wrong somewhere which is causing the PID controllers to give wild results. The reason I say this is because you said :

Christian:

When i move the joystick a liitle bit that what it does it like it doesnt listen to the controller

Which to me reads as : turn the bot on (things are zeroed out and happy), bump the joystick (some input), this behavior happens

It is good the encoder seems to be working if it is giving a value when you turn by hand.

My next question is how your code is utilizing the encoder information?

Is it just using the thrifty encoder it as a seed and controlling the motor with the motor’s built-in encoder or is it using the thrifty encoder value directly for feedback?

I think for much more help you would need to post your code. A link to a github repository is the best method to share.

The value you are passing into your swerve to calculate the turn power encoder angle is the following:

m_turningEncoder.absPosition(encoderOffset)

github.com

christian-923/2025-swerve-main/blob/14afa2408569522e658ddbe519f07759b5ff8539/src/main/java/frc/robot/SwerveModule.java#L134


      
    
          
  1.     SwerveModuleState state =
    2. 
          
  2.         SwerveModuleState.optimize(desiredState, new Rotation2d(m_turningEncoder.absPosition(encoderOffset)));
    3. 
          
  3. 
          
  4.     // Calculate the drive output from the drive PID controller.
    5. 
          
  5.     final double driveOutput =
    6. 
          
  6.         m_drivePIDController.calculate(m_driveEncoder.getVelocity(), state.speedMetersPerSecond);
    7. 
          
  7. 
          
  8.     final double driveFeedforward = m_driveFeedforward.calculate(state.speedMetersPerSecond);
    9. 
          
  9. 
          
  10.     // Calculate the turning motor output from the turning PID controller.
    11. 
          
  11.     final double turnOutput =
    12. 
          
  12.         m_turningPIDController.calculate(m_turningEncoder.absPosition(encoderOffset), state.angle.getRadians());
    13. 
          
  13. 
          
  14.     final double turnFeedforward =
    15. 
          
  15.         m_turnFeedforward.calculate(m_turningPIDController.getSetpoint().velocity);
    16. 
          
  16. 
          
  17.     m_driveMotor.setVoltage(driveOutput + driveFeedforward);
    18. 
          
  18.     m_turningMotor.setVoltage(turnOutput + turnFeedforward);
    19. 
          
  19.   }
    20. 
          
  20. }
    21.

I would recommend updating your SmartDashboard output to the same value that the turn calculator is based on

for example

replace the frontLeft.m_turningEncoder.getDistance()
with frontLeft.m_turningEncoder.absPosition(encoderOffset)

Then turn the module by hand note what the value of this is when it is forward, pointed right, back, and left.

do this for all modules.

image765×326 28.1 KB

This will clear a few things up for me.
